repnme.cdata!:
China - Xinjiang Uyghur (Altai) Snow
            Disaster Recovery Component, and Xinjiang Uyghur (Tacheng)
            Snow Disaster Recovery Component Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was highly likely, the institutional development impact was
            satisfactory, and the Bank and borrower performance were
            both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that despite
            the time pressure during project preparation and appraisal,
            a lot of attention was paid to design details including
            breakdown of costs and procurement down to county level.
            Even more importantly, the scope of the project was well
            focused, and preparation avoided the inclusion of too many
            or too sophisticated components, and the borrower can make a
            significant positive impact in improving the lives of
            lower-income communities, especially in emergency
            situations. The operation showed that rapid and effective
            decisions by both the Bank In emergency reconstruction
            programs, early availability of funds or authorization,
            together with competent business procedures and record
            keeping are essential to address the disaster repairs in a
            timely manner. Procurement procedures have to take into
            account the emergency nature of the project and be
            implemented by well-trained staff. Assisting individual
            households in their recovery from an emergency situation
            requires considerable attention to a well thought-through
            targeting of the limited resources. Due to its emergency
            response nature, the project focused on reconstruction of
            physical and social infrastructure. A strong emphasis on
            input and output monitoring, reporting, and supervision
            contributed to a quality implementation of the project. The
            transfer of this management approaches will serve the
            implementing agencies well in many future activities.

            FUND - 0,TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            while sustainability is rated highly likely. World Bank
            performance is evaluated as satisfactory due to the high
            quality and innovative nature of its lending activities and
            its persistent, yet flexible and supportive role in project
            supervision. Overall government performance is considered
            satisfactory. The following lessons can be learned: The key
            to the project's success or failure is the continuity
            and quality of key personnel on the Borrower's as well
            as on the Association's end: with the right people in
            place, complex urban projects, albeit more time-consuming in
            their preparation and their supervision, can be implemented
            successfully. Turnkey contracts can be a desirable vehicle
            for implementing large water supply or wastewater projects.
            Although the two-stage bidding process may be more
            time-consuming, it normally results in superior technical
            designs and a high quality output. During preparation, it is
            important not only to review the organizational set-up of
            project management, but also to ensure that there is an
            explicit commitment by the authorities to provide adequate
            funding for these units. Cultural preservation of historic
            buildings, if properly integrated with urban development,
            can raise ownership pride and commitment by the implementing
            agencies, and appreciation and support by the citizens. In
            those projects requiring a high degree of technical
            assistance, the selection of good consultants can make or
            break a project.
